title: Leviticus Chapter 27 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Leviticus chapter 27 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Leviticus Chapter 27 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Leviticus Chapter 27.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 27:3, what is the valuation of a male from twenty years old even unto sixty years old?
options: Fifty shekels of silver
Thirty shekels of silver
Twenty shekels of silver
Fifteen shekels of silver
questions.correctAnswer: Fifty shekels of silver
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:3 states that the valuation for a male from twenty years old to sixty years old is fifty shekels of silver.

questions.question: What is the valuation of a female from twenty years old even unto sixty years old according to Leviticus 27?
options: Thirty shekels of silver
Fifty shekels of silver
Ten shekels of silver
Fifteen shekels of silver
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty shekels of silver
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:4 specifies that a female from twenty years old to sixty years old is valued at thirty shekels of silver.

questions.question: If a man is poorer than the valuation, what must he do according to Leviticus 27?
options: Present himself before the priest for valuation
Pay the full valuation anyway
Offer a sacrifice
Be exempt from the vow
questions.correctAnswer: Present himself before the priest for valuation
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:8 instructs that if a person is poorer than the valuation, he shall present himself before the priest who will value him according to his ability.

questions.question: True or False: Leviticus 27:10 allows changing a good beast for a bad one when offering it to the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:10 states that one shall not alter or change a good beast for a bad, or a bad for a good; if changed, both become holy.

questions.question: How much must be added if a person redeems an unclean beast that was valued by the priest?
options: A fifth part of the valuation
Double the valuation
No additional amount
Half the valuation
questions.correctAnswer: A fifth part of the valuation
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:13 explains that if a person redeems an unclean beast, he shall add a fifth part to the valuation.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 27, what happens if someone sanctifies a field after the year of jubilee?
options: The priest shall reckon the money according to the remaining years until jubilee
The field is valued at full price
The field cannot be sanctified
The field becomes the priest's immediately
questions.correctAnswer: The priest shall reckon the money according to the remaining years until jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:18 states that if the field is sanctified after the jubilee, the priest shall reckon the value according to the years remaining until the jubilee.

questions.question: True or False: According to Leviticus 27:20, if a field is sold to another person, it can be redeemed again.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:20 states that if the field is sold to another man, it shall not be redeemed any more.

questions.question: What is the valuation of an homer of barley seed used to sanctify a field, according to Leviticus 27?
options: Fifty shekels of silver
Twenty shekels of silver
Thirty shekels of silver
Ten shekels of silver
questions.correctAnswer: Fifty shekels of silver
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:16 states that an homer of barley seed is valued at fifty shekels of silver when sanctifying a field.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'And all thy estimations shall be according to the ______ of the sanctuary.'
options: shekel
gerah
denarius
pound
questions.correctAnswer: shekel
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:25 specifies that all valuations shall be according to the shekel of the sanctuary.

questions.question: Who receives the possession of the field when it goes out in the jubilee if it has not been redeemed?
options: The priest
The original owner
The person who sanctified it
The Levites
questions.correctAnswer: The priest
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:21 states that the field shall be holy to the LORD and the possession thereof shall be the priest's at the jubilee.

questions.question: True or False: The firstling of beasts can be sanctified and redeemed according to Leviticus 27.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:26 states that the firstling of beasts is the LORD's and no man shall sanctify or redeem it.

questions.question: What must a man add if he redeems part of his tithe according to Leviticus 27?
options: A fifth part of it
Double the amount
Nothing extra
Half the amount
questions.correctAnswer: A fifth part of it
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:31 states that if a man redeems anything of his tithes, he shall add a fifth part to it.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 27, what is holy unto the LORD?
options: All tithes of the land
Only the first fruits
Only the firstborn sons
Only clean animals
questions.correctAnswer: All tithes of the land
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:30 declares that all the tithe of the land, whether seed or fruit, is holy unto the LORD.

questions.question: What happens to devoted things that a man devotes unto the LORD according to Leviticus 27?
options: They shall not be sold or redeemed and are most holy unto the LORD
They can be sold to anyone
They must be redeemed immediately
They become the property of the owner again
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be sold or redeemed and are most holy unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:28 explains that devoted things shall not be sold or redeemed and are most holy unto the LORD.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'None devoted, which shall be devoted of men, shall be ______; but shall surely be put to death.'
options: redeemed
freed
sold
blessed
questions.correctAnswer: redeemed
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:29 states that none devoted of men shall be redeemed but shall surely be put to death.

medium.title: Leviticus Chapter 27 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Leviticus Chapter 27 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with faithfully fulfilling a vow made to God. Based on Leviticus 27, what principle about vows would you share to encourage obedience?
options: Vows must be estimated and fulfilled according to God’s set values
Vows can be altered if circumstances change
Vows are optional and can be ignored without consequence
Only vows of animals must be honored
questions.correctAnswer: Vows must be estimated and fulfilled according to God’s set values
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:2-4 explains that when a person makes a vow, the persons or things vowed must be valued according to God’s set estimations and fulfilled accordingly, emphasizing faithfulness and obedience.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 27 teach about honesty and integrity in daily life related to valuing people who make vows?
options: The priest shall value the vow according to the person's ability
Everyone must pay the highest standard value regardless of ability
Vows can be negotiated with the priest for a lower value
Only wealthy people need to fulfill their vow
questions.correctAnswer: The priest shall value the vow according to the person's ability
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:8 instructs that if someone is poorer than the set estimation, the priest shall value the vow according to the person’s ability, showing fairness and integrity in fulfilling vows.

questions.question: A member of your church is uncertain about redeeming a field they sanctified to the Lord. What biblical principle about redemption would you share from this chapter?
options: Redemption requires adding a fifth part to the estimation
Fields cannot be redeemed once sanctified
Fields are automatically redeemed without cost
Fields must be sold to another before redemption
questions.correctAnswer: Redemption requires adding a fifth part to the estimation
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:13, 15, and 19 teach that if someone wants to redeem a sacred field or animal, they must add a fifth part (20%) to its estimated value, emphasizing commitment and responsibility.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 27 instruct believers about stewardship and generosity regarding tithes?
options: All tithes are holy and belong to the Lord and must not be redeemed without adding a fifth
Tithes can be redeemed freely without penalty
Only a portion of the tithe belongs to the Lord
Tithes are optional and may be kept by the owner
questions.correctAnswer: All tithes are holy and belong to the Lord and must not be redeemed without adding a fifth
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:30-31 states that all tithes are holy to the Lord; if one wishes to redeem part of the tithe, they must add a fifth part, encouraging faithful giving and stewardship.

questions.question: What does Leviticus 27 teach about humility and contentment when valuing individuals for vows?
options: Values are set by age and gender but adjusted for personal ability
Everyone is valued equally regardless of age or gender
Only men’s vows are valued
Values are arbitrary and can be decided by the individual
questions.correctAnswer: Values are set by age and gender but adjusted for personal ability
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:3-7 and 8 explain specific valuations by age and gender but allow adjustments for the poorer person's ability, teaching humility and fairness in fulfilling vows.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with forgiveness and reconciliation after dedicating possessions to the Lord. How might Leviticus 27 guide their heart regarding what is devoted to God?
options: Devoted things are most holy and cannot be redeemed or sold
Devoted things can be redeemed anytime without penalty
One can take back what was devoted if circumstances change
Devoted things lose their holiness after a year
questions.correctAnswer: Devoted things are most holy and cannot be redeemed or sold
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:28 explains that anything devoted to the Lord is most holy and cannot be sold or redeemed, teaching respect and reverence for what belongs to God.

questions.question: How does this chapter teach us about perseverance through trials when making vows or dedicating possessions?
options: Once vowed or dedicated, it must be honored fully even if difficult
Vows can be broken if hardships occur
Dedications are suggestions, not obligations
Items can be exchanged freely after dedication
questions.correctAnswer: Once vowed or dedicated, it must be honored fully even if difficult
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:10 instructs not to alter or exchange vowed items, emphasizing perseverance and faithfulness in honoring commitments to God.

questions.question: True or False: According to Leviticus 27, the firstborn of clean animals may be sanctified and redeemed by an individual.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:26 states that the firstling of clean beasts is the Lord’s and no man shall sanctify it, highlighting God’s ownership over firstborn animals.

questions.question: True or False: Leviticus 27 allows for changing a bad animal for a good one when it is given as an offering to the Lord.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:10 forbids altering or exchanging animals given to the Lord, teaching integrity and respect for vows made.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Leviticus 27, the standard shekel of the sanctuary is equal to ______ gerahs.
options: Twenty
Ten
Thirty
Fifteen
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:25 clarifies that twenty gerahs equal one shekel of the sanctuary, which is the basis for all valuations in the chapter.

questions.question: A believer is teaching their family about the importance of honoring vows and tithes. Based on Leviticus 27, what principle about tithes from herds and flocks would you share?
options: The tenth of the herd or flock is holy to the Lord and must not be changed
Only the best animals in the herd are tithed
Tithes can be redeemed without adding extra value
Tithes are optional for herds and flocks
questions.correctAnswer: The tenth of the herd or flock is holy to the Lord and must not be changed
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:32-33 teaches that a tenth of the herd or flock is holy to the Lord and must not be exchanged or redeemed, emphasizing honesty and integrity in giving.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 27 instruct believers about the value of dedicating houses to the Lord in terms of spiritual discipline and commitment?
options: The priest estimates the house’s value and it stands according to that
Houses can be sanctified without priestly approval
Sanctified houses can be freely redeemed without penalty
Only fields, not houses, can be sanctified
questions.correctAnswer: The priest estimates the house’s value and it stands according to that
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:14-15 states that when a house is sanctified, the priest estimates its value and that valuation stands, teaching respect and commitment in dedicating possessions.

questions.question: A person sanctifies a field after the year of jubilee. According to Leviticus 27, how is the value of that field determined?
options: The priest calculates the value based on the years remaining to the jubilee
The full original value must be paid without reduction
The field cannot be sanctified after the jubilee
The owner sets the value freely
questions.correctAnswer: The priest calculates the value based on the years remaining to the jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:18 explains that if a field is sanctified after the jubilee, the priest shall reckon the money according to the remaining years until the jubilee, showing fairness in valuation.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 27 teach about the seriousness of dedicating people to the Lord in terms of spiritual discipline and obedience?
options: Devoted people shall not be redeemed but put to death
Devoted people can be redeemed by paying a price
Devoted people can be released anytime
Devoted people are exempt from punishment
questions.correctAnswer: Devoted people shall not be redeemed but put to death
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:29 declares that none devoted of men shall be redeemed but must be put to death, underscoring the gravity of dedicating a person to the Lord.

questions.question: How does Leviticus 27 encourage believers to practice contentment and trust in God when making vows about animals that are unclean?
options: The priest values the unclean beast and the owner can redeem it with a fifth part added
Unclean animals are automatically accepted as offerings
Unclean animals cannot be redeemed or valued
Owners can freely exchange unclean animals
questions.correctAnswer: The priest values the unclean beast and the owner can redeem it with a fifth part added
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:11-13 instructs that unclean beasts must be valued by the priest and if redeemed, a fifth part must be added, teaching reliance on God’s established system.

hard.title: Leviticus Chapter 27 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Leviticus Chapter 27.

questions.question: What is the valuation in silver shekels for a male between twenty and sixty years old who makes a special vow to the LORD according to Leviticus 27?
options: Fifty shekels
Thirty shekels
Twenty shekels
Fifteen shekels
questions.correctAnswer: Fifty shekels
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:3 states that the valuation for a male from twenty to sixty years old is fifty shekels of silver, according to the sanctuary shekel.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 27, what must a person do if they are poorer than the standard valuation for a vow they have made?
options: Present themselves before the priest for a valuation
Offer a substitute animal
Make a new vow
Pay the full standard valuation
questions.correctAnswer: Present themselves before the priest for a valuation
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:8 indicates that if someone is poorer than the valuation, they must appear before the priest who will value them according to their ability.

questions.question: What is forbidden when exchanging animals dedicated to the LORD according to Leviticus 27?
options: Altering a good animal for a bad one
Offering unclean animals
Selling the animal to a stranger
Eating the animal before dedication
questions.correctAnswer: Altering a good animal for a bad one
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:10 forbids changing a dedicated animal, such as exchanging a good one for a bad one, ensuring the original vow remains intact.

questions.question: How much extra must be added when redeeming a dedicated animal or property, according to Leviticus 27?
options: One-fifth (20%)
One-tenth (10%)
One-half (50%)
Double the valuation
questions.correctAnswer: One-fifth (20%)
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:13 and 27:15 indicate that a fifth part (20%) must be added to the valuation when redeeming a dedicated animal or property.

questions.question: In Leviticus 27, what is the valuation base used for estimating the worth of a portion of field sanctified to the LORD?
options: An homer of barley seed valued at fifty shekels
A bushel of wheat valued at sixty shekels
A tenth of the crop yield
A standard measure of olive oil
questions.correctAnswer: An homer of barley seed valued at fifty shekels
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:16 specifies that the valuation of sanctified field is based on the seed: an homer of barley seed is valued at fifty shekels of silver.

questions.question: What happens to a field that is dedicated to the LORD and goes out in the year of Jubilee?
options: It becomes holy to the LORD and the priest's possession
It remains with the current owner
It must be sold to another Israelite
It is returned to the Levites
questions.correctAnswer: It becomes holy to the LORD and the priest's possession
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:21 states that a field going out in the Jubilee year becomes holy to the LORD and belongs to the priest as a devoted field.

questions.question: If a man sanctifies a field he bought (not originally his), what happens to the field in the year of Jubilee?
options: The field returns to the original owner
The man keeps the field permanently
The field is sold to the priest
The field is divided among the tribes
questions.correctAnswer: The field returns to the original owner
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:24 explains that in the Jubilee year, the field returns to the person from whom it was bought, restoring original possession.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 27, what is the status of the firstborn of beasts dedicated to the LORD?
options: They are the LORD's and cannot be sanctified by man
They may be redeemed by adding a fifth
They must be sold according to valuation
They can be exchanged for other beasts
questions.correctAnswer: They are the LORD's and cannot be sanctified by man
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:26 declares that the firstborn of beasts are the LORD's firstlings and no one may sanctify them, emphasizing their special status.

questions.question: What is the consequence for a person who devotes a man to the LORD according to Leviticus 27?
options: The person devoted shall surely be put to death
The person may be redeemed by paying a ransom
The person becomes a servant to the priest
The person is released after a year
questions.correctAnswer: The person devoted shall surely be put to death
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:29 states that none devoted of men shall be redeemed but must be put to death, showing the seriousness of such a vow.

questions.question: How are tithes of the land described in relation to the LORD in Leviticus 27?
options: They are holy unto the LORD
They may be redeemed without additional payment
They are to be distributed among the people
They are optional offerings
questions.correctAnswer: They are holy unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:30 declares that all the tithe of the land, whether seed or fruit, is holy unto the LORD, indicating its sacred status.

questions.question: What happens if a man tries to redeem part of his tithe according to Leviticus 27?
options: He must add a fifth part to its value
He may redeem it without penalty
He must offer a substitute animal
He forfeits the tithe entirely
questions.correctAnswer: He must add a fifth part to its value
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:31 states that if a man redeems any of his tithes, he shall add a fifth part to it, similar to other redemption rules.

questions.question: Leviticus 27 forbids searching whether the tithe of herd or flock is good or bad. What is the reason given for this?
options: Both it and the change thereof shall be holy and not redeemed
Only the best animals are accepted as tithe
The tithe must be sacrificed immediately
The animals must be sold to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: Both it and the change thereof shall be holy and not redeemed
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:33 explains that the tithe of the herd or flock shall not be examined for quality nor changed, otherwise both it and the exchange become holy and cannot be redeemed.

questions.question: True or False: According to Leviticus 27, a devoted thing to the LORD may be sold or redeemed at any time.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:28 clearly states that no devoted thing, whether man, beast, or field, shall be sold or redeemed; every devoted thing is most holy unto the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: The valuations and estimations mentioned in Leviticus 27 are based on the shekel of the sanctuary, which is composed of twenty gerahs.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:25 specifies that all valuations are according to the shekel of the sanctuary, which consists of twenty gerahs.

questions.question: What is the significance of the valuation system of persons in Leviticus 27 in relation to ancient Near Eastern social structures?
options: It reflects a structured approach to vows that considers age and gender
It assigns equal value to all individuals regardless of status
It allows for arbitrary priestly valuations unrelated to social norms
It is a system unique to Israel with no parallel in the ancient world
questions.correctAnswer: It reflects a structured approach to vows that considers age and gender
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:2-7 shows a detailed valuation system based on age and gender, reflecting ancient Near Eastern cultural norms where social value and obligations were quantified carefully.

questions.question: How does the concept of 'devoted things' (herem) in Leviticus 27 connect with later biblical themes of holiness and consecration?
options: Devoted things are irrevocably holy and dedicated to the LORD
Devoted things may be redeemed at will
They represent a temporary holy status
They are a metaphor for Israel's exile
questions.correctAnswer: Devoted things are irrevocably holy and dedicated to the LORD
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:28 emphasizes that devoted things are most holy and cannot be sold or redeemed, establishing a theme of irrevocable consecration to God found throughout Scripture.

theological.title: Leviticus Chapter 27 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Leviticus Chapter 27 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 27, what is the required valuation in shekels of silver for a male between twenty and sixty years old who makes a vow?
options: Fifty shekels
Thirty shekels
Twenty shekels
Fifteen shekels
questions.correctAnswer: Fifty shekels
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:3 mandates the valuation of a male aged twenty to sixty at fifty shekels of silver, reflecting the sanctity and worth God assigns according to age and gender. This valuation principle relates to the value of human life and service, consistent with Exodus 30:12-15 and the ransom teachings in Mark 10:45 and 1 Corinthians 6:20.

questions.question: What must happen if someone is poorer than the standard valuation for a vow as described in Leviticus 27?
options: The priest shall value him according to his ability
The vow is nullified
He must pay the full valuation anyway
He must offer an animal sacrifice instead
questions.correctAnswer: The priest shall value him according to his ability
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:8 instructs that if the person is poorer than the standard valuation, the priest assesses the value according to the person's ability. This shows God's justice and mercy, as also seen in Deuteronomy 16:10-17, 2 Corinthians 8:12, and Luke 21:1-4 concerning giving according to ability.

questions.question: In the context of sanctifying animals to the LORD, what is forbidden according to Leviticus 27?
options: Altering or exchanging a good animal for a bad one
Offering unclean animals
Sacrificing without a priest
Giving animals as gifts
questions.correctAnswer: Altering or exchanging a good animal for a bad one
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:10 commands that once an animal is devoted, no substitution of a good animal for a bad one is allowed. This reflects God's demand for integrity and holiness in offerings, consistent with Malachi 1:8, Matthew 5:37, and Hebrews 13:16 which emphasize sincerity and holiness in worship.

questions.question: How is a field valued if it is sanctified after the year of jubilee, according to Leviticus 27?
options: The priest shall reckon the value according to the years remaining until jubilee
It is valued at full price regardless of jubilee
It cannot be sanctified after jubilee
It returns automatically to the priest
questions.correctAnswer: The priest shall reckon the value according to the years remaining until jubilee
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:18 details that if a field is sanctified after jubilee, its value is calculated proportionally to the remaining years until the jubilee year. This reveals God's sovereign order in property and redemption, paralleling principles in Leviticus 25:23-28, Romans 8:21, and Revelation 21:1-5 concerning restoration and redemption.

questions.question: What must be added to the valuation if a person redeems a devoted beast or field?
options: One fifth of the valuation
One tenth of the valuation
Double the valuation
No addition is required
questions.correctAnswer: One fifth of the valuation
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:13 and 27:19 mandate adding one fifth (20%) to the valuation upon redemption. This additional amount underscores the seriousness of vows and consecration, reflecting God's holiness and justice as seen in Exodus 30:12, Numbers 18:16, and 2 Corinthians 8:12.

questions.question: Which animals are specifically stated as not to be sanctified because they are already the LORD's firstlings?
options: Oxen and sheep
Goats and cattle
Birds and fish
Unclean beasts
questions.correctAnswer: Oxen and sheep
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:26 states that the firstlings of beasts, such as oxen and sheep, are the LORD's firstlings and cannot be sanctified since they belong to God by right. This is consistent with Exodus 13:12, Numbers 3:13, and Luke 2:23 which highlight God's claim on firstborn animals and people.

questions.question: What happens to a devoted person who is consecrated to the LORD according to Leviticus 27?
options: They shall not be redeemed but put to death
They may be redeemed by payment
They become priests
They are set free after a year
questions.correctAnswer: They shall not be redeemed but put to death
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:29 clearly states that a person devoted to the LORD is not redeemable but must be put to death, emphasizing the gravity of the vow and the holiness of God. This concept is also seen in Numbers 21:2, Joshua 6:17, and Hebrews 9:27 concerning the seriousness of consecration and judgment.

questions.question: How are tithes of land produce described in Leviticus 27?
options: Holy unto the LORD
To be sold and redeemed
Given to the poor
To be eaten by the priests only
questions.correctAnswer: Holy unto the LORD
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:30 declares that all tithes of the land, whether seeds or fruit, are holy unto the LORD, indicating that all God’s provision is sacred and dedicated to Him. This aligns with Malachi 3:10, Proverbs 3:9, and Matthew 23:23 which affirm the importance of tithing and honoring God with first fruits.

questions.question: If someone sanctifies a field that he has bought, what happens to the field in the year of jubilee according to Leviticus 27?
options: It shall return to the original owner
It remains with the buyer forever
It is given to the priests permanently
It becomes common land
questions.correctAnswer: It shall return to the original owner
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:24 teaches that in the year of jubilee, fields return to their original owners, emphasizing God’s sovereign design for property and social justice. This principle is foundational in Leviticus 25:10, Jeremiah 34:8-17, Luke 4:18-19, and Revelation 21:1-5 concerning restoration and redemption.

questions.question: According to Leviticus 27, what is the valuation for a female from five years old to twenty years old when making a vow?
options: Ten shekels
Thirty shekels
Three shekels
Fifteen shekels
questions.correctAnswer: Ten shekels
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:5 states that a female from five years old to twenty years old is valued at ten shekels, demonstrating differentiated valuation based on age and sex in the ancient covenant context. This valuation corresponds with principles of human worth and sanctity found in Exodus 30:14, Psalm 139:13-16, and 1 Timothy 2:9-15.

questions.question: What is commanded about changing a tithe from one animal to another in Leviticus 27?
options: It shall not be changed; if changed, both the original and the change become holy
It may be exchanged freely
It can be redeemed without penalty
It must be sold to the priests
questions.correctAnswer: It shall not be changed; if changed, both the original and the change become holy
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:33 forbids changing tithes from one animal to another; if done, both become holy and cannot be redeemed. This underscores God's demand for reverence and integrity, echoed in Deuteronomy 12:32, Matthew 5:37, and Hebrews 13:16 emphasizing honesty in offerings.

questions.question: What is the valuation for a male from a month old to five years old when devoted to the LORD, according to Leviticus 27?
options: Five shekels
Twenty shekels
Fifteen shekels
Thirty shekels
questions.correctAnswer: Five shekels
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:6 commands that a male from a month old to five years old is valued at five shekels, showing the age-based scale of valuation in vows and sanctification. This emphasizes the recognition of personhood and value from infancy, consistent with Job 3:11, Luke 18:15-17, and Psalm 127:3.

questions.question: If a man sanctifies his house to the LORD, what is the procedure for its valuation and redemption according to Leviticus 27?
options: The priest estimates its value; if redeemed, a fifth part is added
The house is automatically holy and not redeemable
The owner must pay double the market price
The house is sold to the priests immediately
questions.correctAnswer: The priest estimates its value; if redeemed, a fifth part is added
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:14-15 explains that the priest estimates the sanctified house's value, and if the owner redeems it, he must add a fifth part. This reflects God's justice and provision for redemption, similar to principles in Leviticus 25:24-28, Isaiah 55:7, and Luke 15:11-32 about valuation and restoration.

questions.question: What is the shekel of the sanctuary equal to in gerahs, according to Leviticus 27?
options: Twenty gerahs
Ten gerahs
Thirty gerahs
Fifty gerahs
questions.correctAnswer: Twenty gerahs
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:25 clarifies that the shekel of the sanctuary consists of twenty gerahs, defining the sacred currency for valuations and offerings. This precise standard reflects God's order and justice, as seen also in Exodus 30:13, Ezekiel 45:12, and Acts 18:27 concerning weights and measures.

questions.question: What status is given to all devoted things that a man dedicates to the LORD, according to Leviticus 27?
options: They are most holy and cannot be sold or redeemed
They can be redeemed at any time
They may be exchanged for other offerings
They become common property of the tribe
questions.correctAnswer: They are most holy and cannot be sold or redeemed

questions.question: According to Leviticus 27, what happens if someone sanctifies a field but does not redeem it before the jubilee?
options: The field becomes holy to the LORD and belongs to the priest
The field remains with the sanctifier permanently
The field is sold to another person
The field is given to the poor
questions.correctAnswer: The field becomes holy to the LORD and belongs to the priest
questions.explanation: Leviticus 27:21 states that if the field is not redeemed, it becomes holy to the LORD and the possession of the priests at jubilee, emphasizing divine ownership and priestly stewardship. This aligns with Leviticus 25:23-34, Numbers 18:20-24, and Hebrews 7:1-10 concerning God's ownership and priestly rights.
